section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 6. Chapter 6: Diseases of the Nervous System > b. Pain - Category G89 > 5) Neoplasm Related Pain

content.full_text: Code G89.3 is assigned to pain documented as being related, associated or due to cancer, primary or secondary malignancy, or tumor. This code is assigned regardless of whether the pain is acute or chronic. This code may be assigned as the principal or first-listed code when the stated reason for the admission/encounter is documented as pain control/pain management. The underlying neoplasm should be reported as an additional diagnosis. When the reason for the admission/encounter is management of the neoplasm and the pain associated with the neoplasm is also documented, code G89.3 may be assigned as an additional diagnosis. It is not necessary to assign an additional code for the site of the pain. See Section I.C.2. for instructions on the sequencing of neoplasms for all other stated reasons for the admission/encounter (except for pain control/pain management). (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62-L63)
content.summary: Comprehensive guidelines for coding neoplasm-related pain using G89.3, including sequencing rules for pain control vs neoplasm management encounters. (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62-L63)
key_concepts: G89.3 for neoplasm-related pain (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62)
Acute/chronic distinction irrelevant (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62)
Principal code for pain control encounters (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62-L63)
Additional code for neoplasm management encounters (Evidence: pg no: 48, L63)
No site code needed (Evidence: pg no: 48, L63)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code G89.3 is assigned to pain documented as being related, associated or due to cancer, primary or secondary malignancy, or tumor. This code is assigned regardless of whether the pain is acute or chronic (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62)
detailed_rules.explanation: G89.3 is used for all cancer-related pain regardless of acute or chronic nature (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62)

detailed_rules.rule_text: This code may be assigned as the principal or first-listed code when the stated reason for the admission/encounter is documented as pain control/pain management. The underlying neoplasm should be reported as an additional diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62-L63)
detailed_rules.explanation: For pain control encounters, G89.3 is principal with neoplasm as additional diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 48, L62-L63)

detailed_rules.rule_text: When the reason for the admission/encounter is management of the neoplasm and the pain associated with the neoplasm is also documented, code G89.3 may be assigned as an additional diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 48, L63)
detailed_rules.explanation: For neoplasm management encounters, G89.3 is additional diagnosis when pain is documented (Evidence: pg no: 48, L63)

detailed_rules.rule_text: It is not necessary to assign an additional code for the site of the pain (Evidence: pg no: 48, L63)
detailed_rules.explanation: G89.3 is sufficient for neoplasm-related pain without additional site-specific codes (Evidence: pg no: 48, L63)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify pain related to cancer/tumor/malignancy
Step 2: Assign G89.3 regardless of acute/chronic nature
Step 4: If pain control, use G89.3 as principal, neoplasm as additional
Step 5: If neoplasm management, use neoplasm as principal, G89.3 as additional
Step 6: Do not assign additional site codes

Step 2: Note encounter is for pain control/management
Step 3: Assign G89.3 as principal diagnosis
Step 4: Assign neoplasm code as additional diagnosis

Step 3: Assign lung cancer as principal diagnosis
Step 4: Assign G89.3 as additional diagnosis for documented pain
